Painesdale Mine and Shaft https://www.nps.gov/places/painesdale-mine-and-shaft.htm By preserving and restoring the Champion #4 Shaft-Rockhouse, Painesdale Mine & Shaft, Inc. hopes to continue using it as a museum so that future generations can experience the sights, sounds, smells, and the feel of mining as it once was. Along with the #4 Shaft House, there remains numerous industrial buildings, railway equipment, and private homes related to the mining area. PM&S Inc. hopes to someday identify these structures so that the full story of what life was like in Painesdale can be told.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.

properties.name: Parade Grounds
properties.notes:
Parade Grounds
https://www.nps.gov/places/parade-grounds.htm

For many years, a grassy area along Calumet Ave between Depot Street and Red Jacket Road served as a parade ground. For generations, soldiers of the Calumet Light Guard, National Guard, and ROTC drilled here. Festivals were held on the grounds, and troops camped here during a major labor strike in 1913-14. Three of the buildings that stood on the edge of the parade ground (an armory, a church, and painting shop) are gone. Part of the parade ground is now occupied by new construction.

properties.name: Pattern Shop
properties.notes:
Pattern Shop
https://www.nps.gov/places/pattern-shop.htm

Calumet & Hecla's location away from distant manufacturing centers required the company to be self-reliant. The pattern shop is located in the center of Calumet’s industrial core. The building is a large single-story structure made from yellow brick with a shallow-pitched gabled roof. Originally the building was divided in the center to house both a pattern workshop and warehouse. Here, skilled workers crafted patterns used in the foundry to cast needed parts or tools. The pattern shop is now home to Coppertown USA Mining Museum.

properties.name: Pattern Storage Warehouse
properties.notes:
Pattern Storage Warehouse
https://www.nps.gov/places/pattern-storage-warehouse.htm

The pattern storage warehouse served as a giant repository for the over 30,000 patterns that Calumet & Hecla used with “green” sand to cast machine parts and tools. The building is a two-story structure made of poor-rock, red and white Jacobsville sandstone blocks on the corners, and brick trim above the windows and doors. A single-story dry house, a location for miners to hang their wet and dirty clothes after the shift, was attached to this building. You can compare a pattern warehouse to a 3D printer’s library of files.

properties.name: Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park
properties.notes:
Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park https://www.nps.gov/places/porcupine-mountains-wilderness-state-park.htm In addition to wild forests and lakeshores, Michigan’s largest state park has numerous historic copper mining sites. The 59,020-acre park offers summer and winter recreational pursuits and interpretive programs. The park hosts a 35,000-acre old-growth forest amounts its waterfalls, rivers, trails, campgrounds, and Lake Superior shoreline.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.

properties.name: Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse
properties.notes:
Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-2-shaft-rockhouse.htm

A part of one of the Keweenaw’s most profitable and long-lasting copper mines, the No. 2 Shafthouse stands over the shaft where men would go underground to work and where copper-bearing rock was brought up from below. One of several mine shafts at the Quincy location, the #2 was the longest, extending over 9,000 feet along the angle and reaching an overall depth of 6,225 feet below the surface. Men mining on the 92nd level would have spent their entire 8-hour shift working more than a mile underground in 90-degree heat. Over time without use the shafthouse severely rusted, leading it to be resided in the mid-1980s - an early preservation effort by the Quincy Mine Hoist Association.

properties.name: Quincy #4 Boiler House
properties.notes:
Quincy #4 Boiler House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-4-boiler-house.htm

The #4 Boiler House used its coal fired boilers to produce steam to power equipment such as hoisting engines. The boiler house was originally a two-story structure made from poor-rock with arched brick detailing above the windows and doors. Four boiler sets sat in brick surrounds inside the building. Two 18-foot tall stone chimneys sat next to the building, one on each of the northern and southern faces. Between 1888 and 1908 a single-story wooden addition was added onto the west corner of the building’s southern face. By 1942 the boiler house sat vacant and the boilers had been removed.

properties.name: Quincy #4 Hoist House
properties.notes:
Quincy #4 Hoist House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-4-hoist-house.htm

The #4 Boiler House provided power for lifting rock and moving workers at the #4 shaft.

properties.name: Quincy #4 Shafthouse Ruins
properties.notes:
Quincy #4 Shafthouse Ruins
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-4-shafthouse-ruins.htm

Once a productive shaft for Quincy, the #4 plunged thousands of feet into the ground. The house itself was a 50-foot tall wooden building with a wire running southeast to the engine house. Today all that remains is the poor-rock foundation of the shafthouse. The building that used to cover the shaft allowed for some initial sorting of the ore coming from underground.

properties.name: Quincy #5 Boiler House
properties.notes:
Quincy #5 Boiler House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-5-boiler-house.htm

The neighboring "world's largest steam hoist" required a massive amount of steam to operate. In the #5 Boiler House, eight coal-fired boilers boiled water, producing this steam. The building is a tall single-story structure made from yellow brick. A shorter single-story addition with gable roof can be seen on the southwestern face of the boiler house. Steel trusses supported the roof and the walls were covered in plaster. In recent years, stabilization has occurred, preventing further building deterioration. Do not enter this building as ruins can be unstable.

properties.name: Quincy #7 Boiler House
properties.notes:
Quincy #7 Boiler House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-7-boiler-house.htm

The #7 Boiler House supplied steam to power for equipment like steam hoisting engines. This building housed two groups of four boilers which were separated by brick partitions. Coal fired boilers boiled water, producing the necessary steam. The steam flowed through pipes to provide power to machines sometimes located far away from the boiler house. Decorative features on the #7 boiler building include red brick archways over the doors and windows along with Jacobsville Sandstone quoins or building corners. An air pump was housed in an attached addition on the western face of the building and a stone chimney also stood next to the building on this side.

properties.name: Quincy & Torch Lake RR Water Tower
properties.notes:
Quincy & Torch Lake RR Water Tower
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-torch-lake-rr-water-tower.htm

Locomotives on the Quincy & Torch Lake railroad ran on steam, which required a water source. This stop, located next to the locomotive house and car repairing shop, was used to replenish the train’s water supplies. Due to the steep slope of the ground in this location the water tower sits on large wooden scaffolding. Recent conservation work on the building finished in 2019 which updated its exterior and preserved it for future generations.

properties.name: Quincy 1882 Hoist House
properties.notes:
Quincy 1882 Hoist House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-1882-hoist-house.htm

Built in 1882, this structure housed the second hoist for the #2 shaft. The building is a tall single-story structure made from poor-rock with arched brick details over the windows and door. Recent preservation includes the addition of a new roof, tuckpointing, and window coverings. Original dormers have been removed. In 1894 the company built a new hoist for the #2 just down the hill.

properties.name: Quincy 1894 Hoist House
properties.notes:
Quincy 1894 Hoist House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-1894-hoist-house.htm

This hoist house was the 3rd in succession to serve the #2 shaft. The building is a 22-foot tall single story made from rough red and white Jacobsville sandstone with clean cut blocks to highlight the buildings corners and sides of windows and doors. Decorative red-brick arches can be seen above the windows and doors. Long since removed, the hoist inside raised copper rock and moved men to and from their worksites underground. The building and museum inside are now part of the Quincy Mine paid tour.

properties.name: Quincy Mine
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine.htm The Quincy mine was owned and operated by the Quincy Mining Company from 1864 to 1945 and was known as “Old Reliable.” The moniker came from the company regularly paying dividends to investors from 1868 until 1920. Portions of over a dozen buildings stand for visitors to see and experience. On a two-hour tour, visitors take a guided walk through the hoist house, ride a cog-rail tram, and enter the mine to learn about mining life. Shorter, surface-only tours are also available.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.

properties.name: Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine-1918-hoist-house.htm

Years into the mining decline, Quincy Mine flouted its optimism for the future by investing over $300,000 to house the world's largest steam hoist. The building to house the hoist is an extravagant structure is made of reinforced concrete with a brick veneer. Finishing touches include a green glazed tile roof, which has been removed, white tile interior, and brass railings. Recent rehabilitation includes exterior concrete repair and structural stabilization.

properties.name: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine-dryhouse-ruins.htm

The Quincy Mine provided dryhouses where miners could change into work clothes at the beginning of a shift and back into home clothes at the end of the day. At the end of shift, miners could wash up, while work clothing was hung to dry. You may notice different colors of mortar, which may indicate previous preservation efforts. This dryhouse was a two-story structure made from poor-rock.

properties.name: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins Parking
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins Parking
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine-dryhouse-ruins-parking.htm

The parking area for the Quincy Dryhouse Ruins has two trailheads. One leads to the dryhouse and one to an overview of the historic Quincy landscape. A picnic table is available for use. Nearby rock outcroppings show evidence of glaciation.

properties.name: Quincy Mine Engine House
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine Engine House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine-engine-house.htm

Built in 1889, the Quincy Engine House served as a maintenance garage for the Quincy & Torch Lake Railroad. What began with 2 bays, soon became 3, and ultimately 4, signifying Quincy's growth at the time. The engine house is a tall single-story structure made from poor-rock and has a shallow-sloped flat roof. Brick arch details can be seen above the windows. Recent preservation includes tuckpointing, a new roof, windows, and doors.

properties.name: Quincy Mine Gift Shop (Supply Office)
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine Gift Shop (Supply Office)
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine-gift-shop-supply-office.htm

The Quincy Mine supply office was built in 1893 at an expense of just over $9,000. The supply office housed an array of mining supplies, from mine lamps to drill steels. The building is a two-story structure with gabled roof and raised foundation. The foundation is made from poor rock while the building is made from red and white Jacobsville sandstone with polished pieces to highlight the corners of the structure and the edges of windows. Arched red brick detail can be seen above the windows and doors. In the early 1990s the building was refurbished into its current use: the Quincy Mine Gift Shop.

properties.name: Quincy Mine Man Engine Shaft
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine Man Engine Shaft
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine-man-engine-shaft.htm

In early years, miners climbed ladders to and from their work sites underground. Being both grueling and dangerous, Quincy installed a man engine. This mechanical ladder system proved useful and efficient but was abandoned in the early 1890s due to the depth of Quincy. The shaft is now capped with a "bat-friendly" enclosure, one of two on the Quincy site.

properties.name: Quincy Mine Pay Office
properties.notes:
Quincy Mine Pay Office
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-mine-pay-office.htm

Situated on the south end of Quincy Mine property, The Quincy Mine Pay Office is a prominent reminder of past corporate paternalism. Built of local Jacobsville sandstone with slate roof, this two-story structure replaced the previous office in 1897. Recent preservation efforts include new roofing, windows, and surrounding fence.

properties.name: Quincy Oil House
properties.notes:
Quincy Oil House
https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-oil-house.htm

Now known as the oil house, this building was used to dispense carbide for miner's lamps. Carbide, when mixed with water, would emit a burnable gas. This would be the most advanced personal lighting ever in use at Quincy. This building is a single story made from red and white Jacobsville sandstone. Brick arch detail can be seen over the entrance door. Recent stabilization includes a new roof and tuckpointing, ensuring building stability.

properties.name: Quincy Smelter
properties.notes:
Quincy Smelter https://www.nps.gov/places/quincy-smelter.htm The Quincy Mining Company built the Quincy Smelting Works on the banks of the Portage Canal in 1898. Quincy constructed the smelter to refine and ship its own copper, as well as to accept custom work from neighboring mining operations. In 1978, the Historic American Engineering Record documented the smelter complex in its study of the Quincy Mining Company. Due to the integrity of the historic resources at the site, the National Park Service then included the complex in the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District, and ultimately within the boundaries of Keweenaw National Historical Park.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.

properties.name: Russell Snowplow
properties.notes:
Russell Snowplow
https://www.nps.gov/places/russell-snowplow.htm

With over 200 inches of annual snowfall, keeping the rail lines open was an endless but necessary task. Without its own power, a steam locomotive "pushed" the snowplow to clear rail lines. Nearby, you may see evidence of historic railways once used to carry people, supplies, or equipment.

properties.name: Sand Storage
properties.notes:
Sand Storage
https://www.nps.gov/places/sand-storage.htm

Calumet and Hecla’s sand storage building is located next to its pattern and foundry facilities. Sand was used in the foundry for casting tools and parts. A large supply was kept at this location. This building is a single-story structure of poured concrete and has a flat roof.

properties.name: Superior Boiler House
properties.notes:
Superior Boiler House
https://www.nps.gov/places/superior-boiler-house.htm

Beneath tall, billowing stacks, coal-fired boilers boiled water. Here, the mine produced steam to power a wide array of steam powered surface equipment. These included steam hoists, which raised copper from deep underground. The boiler house is a three-part structure. One is the red brick chimney. Next to it is a tall poor-rock building with a steep hipped-roof with a small brick chimney rising out of it. The third portion is a red and white Jacobsville sandstone building with a gabled roof.

properties.name: Temple Square Calumet
properties.notes:
Temple Square Calumet
https://www.nps.gov/places/temple-square-calumet.htm

C&H donated, leased, or sold land in this area, also labeled Temple Square on early maps, for the building of numerous churches or community buildings. Managers often supported churches because they asssumed attendees would be moral, loyal and more productive. Religious beliefs and traditions provided many residents with a sence of community.

properties.name: The Calumet Colosseum
properties.notes: The Calumet Colosseum https://www.nps.gov/places/the-calumet-colosseum.htm Originally constructed to house a hockey rink in 1913, the Colosseum also had removeable wooden floors for roller-skating and housed dances and conventions. After serving a dual purpose for decades as the armory for Calumet’s National Guard, today the Colosseum is home to the Calumet Hockey Association and the Calumet Copper Kings. It is considered the oldest purpose-built hockey rink in the United States.
